Barret Morton
Exhibit 5

H-10983-09
PAGE 2
GIST:
On Saturday August 8, 2008, at 10:00PM Detective Barret Morton was assigned an
investigation into the shooting deaths of Patrice Commodore and Jessie Bibbins. Earlier
this date Jessie Bibbins and Kendall Gordon kicked in the front door of Patrice
Commodore's residence. Both masked perpetrators demanded all the occupants of the
residence lay on the floor. The perpetrators then demanded money and vehicle keys
During the course of the home invasion Patrice Commodore was confronted by Jessie
Bibbins at the entrance of her bedroom. At that point the witnesses heard one gunshot.
Gordon and Bibbins then fled the residence of foot. Minutes later Jessie Bibbins was
found unresponsive on the front lawn of 1713 Mazant Street. Bibbins suffered a single
gunshot wound to the neck
Patrice Commodore was treated on the scene by Emergency Medical Technicians and
was pronounced dead at 10:00PM by Doctor Ronald Vasari of University Medical
Center. Jessie Bibbins was treated on the scene at 1713 Mazant Street by Emergency
Medical Technicians. Bibbins was pronounced dead on the scene at 10:32PM also by
Doctor Vasari.
While on the Tricou Street scene Detective Morton met with Fifth District Detective
Gregory Johnson, who advised him the perpetrator described by the eyewitnesses with
tattoos of crosses on his face matched the description of a subject known to Fifth District
Officers as "Kendall Gordon". With the information provided by Detective Johnson
Detective Morton developed Kendall Gordon, black male, of 1424 Kentucky Street as a
suspect.
A member of the Jessie Bibbins' family, Nicole Johnson, identified his remains on the
Mazant Street Scene. Based on the description given by one of the two eyewitnesses to
the Tricou Street shooting, and the proximity of two scenes Jessie Bibbins, black male of
1815 Carondelet Street, was developed as a suspect.
Homicide Investigators interviewed two eyewitnesses at the Homicide Office.
Darceleen Commodore advised Detective Morton she observed the suspect's faces and
knew one of the subjects from the neighborhood. Witness Earlita Taylor stated she did
not see the perpetrator's faces
Via photographic line-up Darceleen Commodore positively identified Kendall Gordon
as one of the two subjects, who entered her home at gunpoint. Commodore was 90% sure
the second subject was Jessie Bibbins. Based on the information received during the
course of the investigation and the positive identification of Kendall Gordon an arrest
warrant was issued for Gordon for two counts of First Degree Murder.

H-10983-09
PAGE 3
On Sunday August 9, at around 5:00PM, Kendal Gordon surrendered to members of
the New Orleans Police Department at the Fifth District Station. Gordon made no
statements to police.
VICTIM:
1987, 1810 Tricou Street, New Orleans
1) Patrice Commodore, black female,
1990, 1815 Carondelet Street, New Orleans
2) Jessie Bibbins, black male,
WOUNDS:
1) Patrice Commodore suffered a fatal gunshot wound to the head, a gunshot wound
to the right wrist, and a gunshot wound to the right arm.
2) Jessie Bibbins suffered a single gunshot wound to the neck puncturing the Aorta,
causing massive interval bleeding.
PERPITRATORS:
1989, 1424 Kentucky Street, New Orleans
1) Kendall Gordon, black male
1990, 1815 Carondelet Street, New Orleans
2) Jessie Bibbins, black male,
MOTIVE:
Burglary
DATE & TIME:
Saturday August 8, 2009, at 10:00PM

PAGE 4
H-10983-09
LOCATION:
1810 Tricou Street, New Orleans, Louisiana

H-10983-09
PAGE 5
Crime Lab Units

Unit 5137
EVIDENCE:
The following objects were confiscated by Technician Shahid Muhammad at 1810
Tricou Street on Sunday August 9, 2009, at 12:02AM. The objects were logged into
Central Evidence & Property by the Technician under Control Number 200912717.
Ex-1) Three blood samples
Ex-2) Seven blood samples
Ex-3) Shards of broken glass with blood
Ex-4) Five blood samples
Ex-5) Two spent "Win" Luger 9mm casings
Ex-6) One blood stained plastic clove
Ex-7) One GSR kit ( Earlietta Taylor)
Ex-8) One GSR kit ( Darceleen Commodore)
Ex-9) One Smith and Wesson Pistol, SW40VE, . 40 caliber
Ex-10) One Smith and Wesson Magazine
Ex-11) Six CCI N-R .40 caliber live rounds
Ex-12) One CCI N-R .40 caliber round
Ex-13) Three CBC .40 Caliber live rounds
Ex-14) Two .40 Caliber Winchester live rounds

H-10983-09
PAGE 6
The following objects were confiscated by Detective David Trehan at the New
Orleans Forensic Center Tuesday, August 11, 2009, at 11:00AM. The objects were
logged into Central Evidence & Property by the Detective under Control Number
200912839.
Ex-15) One spent pellet ( Patrice Commodore)
Ex-16) One inked fingerprint card ( Patrice Commodore)
Ex-17) One spent pellet ( Jessie Bibbins )
Ex-18) One inked fingerprint card ( Jessie Bibbins )
The following evidence was collected by Detective Barret Morton at the New Orleans
Police Headquarters. The objects were logged into Central Evidence & Property under
Control Number 200912867.
Ex-19) Two photographic line-ups
Ex-20) Two audio cassette tapes
The following objects were confiscated by Detective Barret Morton at the New
Orleans Forensic Center Tuesday, August 11, 2009, at 4:00PM. The objects were logged
into Central Evidence & Property by the Detective under Control Number 200912867.
Collected from victim Patrice Commodore
Ex- 21) One pair of blue jeans
Ex-22) One black bra
Ex-23) One woman's top, multicolored

Ex-25) One black T-shirt

H-10983-09
PAGE 7

PERSONS INTERVIEWED:
1) Curtis Palrean, black male,
1953, 3820 Chriswood Drive, Harvey, no

( audio taped statement)
SCENE DESCRIPTION
1810 Tricou Street was a double residence, with 1808 sharing the structure towards
the rear. Detective Morton noted that the residence was positioned on the west side of the
street, with the front door of 1810 facing the street. The structure consisted of a single
story and comprised of a yellow colored brick. The front of the structure contained a
white colored front door, which was illuminated by an overhead porch light and was
covered by a small overhang. Above this door, Detective Morton observed a small
surveillance camera mounted to the wall. Two small patches of grass were situated in
front of the residence and were divided by a concrete walkway which lead to the front
door. Detective Morton noted that four (4) orange evidence cones were positioned in
front of the residence and traveled away from the house as indicated by there ascending
numbers. Detective Morton was advised that these four (4) evidence cones marked a
blood trail which traveled from the interior of the residence to the front yard of the
residence. These cones were identified as numbers 3, 4, 5 and 6. They marked the
following evidence:
#3- Blood spatter from the ground under the front door overhang, commonly identified as
a porch
#4- Blood spatter in the driveway of 1808 Tricou Street.
#5- Blood spatter in the driveway of 1808 Tricou Street.

H-10983-09
PAGE 9
#6- Blood spatter from the grassy area in front of 1810 Tricou Street, to the left side of
the walkway.
To the north of the residence was a concrete driveway which contained two vehicles
parked in a line, one behind the other. The vehicle parked nearest to the residence was a
black colored Lexus, bearing a Vehicle Identification Number of JT8BH68X3W0006181.
In front of the Lexus, close to the street was a gray colored Pontiac Grand Prix, bearing a
Vehicle Identification Number of 2G2WP522441293885. Neither of these vehicles
contained a license plate.
After documenting the blood trail and the exterior of the residence, Detective Morton
entered through the aforementioned front door, which was ajar. Detective Morton noted
that interior of the residence was small and somewhat cluttered. The temperature inside
of the house felt like a comfortable 72 degrees. The first room encountered after entering
the front door appeared to be a living room of sorts. The walls in this room were painted
a white color, as were all the walls inside of the residence. The flooring consisted of a
white colored ceramic tile and was continuous throughout the residence. Typical living
room furniture was observed in the room, such as a coffee table, a television and a
computer desk. Detective Morton also noted other items, such as lawn equipment in this
room. Detective Morton located a piece of wood, which was similar to that of a section of
door frame. Detective Morton checked the interior front door and observed that a piece
was missing from its intended location and was on the floor in the first room. On top of
the coffee table, which was near the south wall of the room was a laptop computer, which
appeared to be on. Detective Morton noted smeared blood on the floor as well as blood
on the lid of a translucent container which was in the middle of the first room on the
floor. In furtherance, Detective Morton could sense that a disturbance happened in this
room, based on the haphazard placement of the furniture and the apparent blood found
throughout.
To the southwest of the first room, Detective Morton encountered an opening in the
wall construction which lead to four other rooms. From this entranceway, Detective
Morton noted a bathroom to the north side of the residence, a kitchen to the west side of
the residence, with an attached laundry room, a bedroom decorated in a children's theme
to the southwest of the residence and another bedroom to the east. Detective Morton
noted that there were two orange evidence cones marking items of evidentiary value in
the interior of the residence. These cones were identified as numbers 1 and 2. Detective
Morton noted that cone #1 was near the doorway of the bathroom between the kitchen
and the living room. In furtherance, Detective Morton observed that cone #1 marked a
spent bullet casing, which was located behind a partially used bag of Beneful brand dry
dog food. Cone #2 was located in the southwest bedroom and that it marked a silver and
black colored semi-automatic handgun. The kitchen was furnished with common
household appliances. In addition to these appliances, Detective Morton observed a
copious amount of shoe boxes and plastic bags containing an assortment of white and
black colored T-shirts.

H-10983-09
PAGE 10
In the doorway to the bedroom which was positioned to east side of the residence,
Detective Morton observed the lifeless body of a black female in the prone position on
the floor. The female decedent was attired in a multi-colored blouse and blue jean pants,
her feet void of socks or shoes. The decedent's legs were positioned to the east, while her
head was positioned to west. The decedent's right arm was tucked beneath her torso and
bent at the elbow, causing her right hand to point south. Her left arm was positioned on
the left side of her body and bent at the elbow in the form of a 90 degree angle, with her
upper arm resting near her head and pointed to the north. A large pool of semi-coagulated
blood was pooled around her head and upper torso, while a copious amount of blood
spatter with downward trajectory was present on a wall which linked the two bedrooms.
This blood was approximately two to three feet from the floor and was to the south of the
decedent. Two distinctive bloody shoe prints were present near the decedent's feet within
the confines of the bedroom.
NARRATIVE:
Detective Barret Morton of the New Orleans Police Department's Homicide Section
respectfully reports the shooting deaths of Patrice Commodore and Jessie Bibbins. The
incident was reported on Saturday August 8, 2009, at around 10:00PM, at 1810 Tricou
Street, New Orleans, Louisiana. Patrice Commodore was pronounced dead on the scene
at 10:00PM by Doctor Ronald Vasari of University Medical Center. Jessie Bibbins was
pronounced dead on the secondary scene, 1713 Mazant Street, at 10:32PM also by
Doctor Vasari. The case is being handled under New Orleans Police Department item
number H-10983-09.
On Saturday August 8, 2009 at 10:00PM, Detective Morton was notified by Detective
Sergeant Daniel McMullen of a signal 30-S, Homicide by Shooting, at 1810 Tricou
Street. While enroot Detective Morton was advised by Detective Desmond Pratt that a
subject had been found shot in the 1700 block of Mazant Street, who matched the
physical description given by the eyewitness at the Tricou crime scene. Detective
Morton arrived at 1820 Tricou at around 10:20PM and began an on-scene investigation.
Detective Morton met with Sergeant McMullen, who advised the Detective the deceased,
Patrice Commodore, had expired inside the residence and was shot once in the head
during a home invasion burglary. There were two eyewitnesses to the incident, who were
inside the residence at the tie of the shooting, Darceleen Commodore and Earlitta Taylor,
and the witnesses were being transported to the Homicide Office for interviews. Sergeant
McMullen advised Detective Morton there was a blood trail from the interior hallway
were the victim is located to North Derbignay Street. Detective Morton observed the
blood trail on the front porch and found the pattern consistent with a subject bleeding
while in motion.

...
H-10983-09
PAGE 11
At 10:33PM, Detective Morton entered the residence. The front door had been forced
open breaking the frame near the knob. The living room had been ransacked. The five
rooms of the residence are linked by a common hallway. Victim, Patrice Commodore,
was observed lying facedown on the floor between the front bedroom and hallway. The
victim suffered an apparent gunshot wound to the head. She was clad in a multicolored
top, blue jeans, and a black bra. In the second bedroom of the residence the detective
observed a .40 caliber handgun on the floor approximately three feet inside the door. In
the kitchen the Detective observed packaging containing white t-shirts, black t-shirts,
Nike sneakers, and baseball caps. The merchandise appeared to be new and unused.
While on the Tricou Street scene Detective Morton met with Fifth District Detective
Gregory Johnson, who advised him the perpetrator described by the eyewitnesses with
tattoos of crosses on his face matches the description of a subject known to Fifth District
Officers as "Kendall Gordon". With the information provided by Detective Johnson
Detective Morton developed Kendall Gordon, black male, of 1424 Kentucky Street as a
suspect.
On Sunday August 9, at 12:10AM the Crime Lab began processing the crime scene
directed by Detective Ryan Aucoin. Detective Aucoin instructed the Crime Lab personnel
to place evidence markers near the trail of blood which traversed the living room to the
front door of the residence. Detective Aucoin also instructed the Crime Lab personnel to
fix and sketch the broken piece of doorjamb into the scene sketch which was being
performed by Scientific Criminal Investigations Division Officer Gary Sallienger. Below
is a list of evidence marked as well as the time it was collected by the Crime Lab .:
Evidence Marker #7- Blood sample from the living room floor near the entry to the
remaining rooms, collected at 12:16am.
Evidence Marker #8- Blood sample from the lid of a container in the living room near
the broken piece of doorjamb, collected at 12:18am.
Evidence Marker #9- Blood sample from the living room floor near the front door,
collected at 12:20am.
Evidence Marker #10- Blood sample from the floor by the north wall under a window in
the living room, collected at 12:21am.
On Sunday, August 9th, 2009 at about 12:22am, Technician Muhammad collected the
shell casing marked by evidence marker #1. this casing was identified as a "Win" 9mm
Luger.

H-10983-09
PAGE 12
At about 12:26am, Technician Muhammad collected the aforementioned firearm from
the bedroom located in the southwest corner of the residence. This firearm had been
marked with evidence marker #2. The firearm was identified as being a Smith and
Wesson .40 caliber handgun, Model SW40VE, serial number PDP1477. This firearm was
loaded with twelve (12) .40 caliber live rounds.
At about 12:27am, Orleans Parish Coroner's Office Investigator Purnell Lewis, unit
7297, entered the residence in order to conduct his portion of the investigation.
At about 12:31am, Investigator Lewis, with the assistance of Chauffer Rodney
Robinson rolled the decedent over and placed her in a body bag. When the decedent was
moved, investigators observed a single spent casing in the pool of blood where the
decedent had been laying. Technician Muhammad photographed and collected the spent
casing, which was identified as a "Win" 9mm Luger at 12:31am.
At about 12:45am, Sergeant Daniel McMullen, unit 4150, located a secondary blood
trail further south of the residence towards the corner of North Roman Street. This blood
trail picked back up in front of 1800 Tricou Street, which was at the corner of North
Roman and Tricou Streets and traveled south, ultimately coming to an end in the 6200
block of North Roman Street. The location, evidence marker number and the time of
collection for the blood samples from this trail are as follows:
Evidence Marker #11- Blood sample from the walkway in front of 1800 Tricou Street,
collected at 12:47am.
Evidence Marker #12- Blood sample from the driveway of 1800 Tricou Street, collected
at 12:48am.
Evidence Marker #13- Blood sample from the driveway of 1800 Tricou Street, collected
at 12:51 am.
Evidence Marker #14- Blood sample from the driveway of 1800 Tricou Street, collected
at 12:52am.
Evidence Marker #15- Blood sample from the street in the 6200 block of North Roman
Street, collected at 12:57am.
Detective Morton proceeded to the second crime scene, 1713 Mazant Street, where
Jessie Bibbins was found seated on the front steps of a residence at 1713 Mazant. Bibbins
suffered an apparent single gunshot wound to the base of the neck. Bibbins was fully clad
in black Nike sneakers, black pants, a black t-shirt, and a red bandana. Matching the
description given to the initial responding officers to the Tricou Street scene by witness
Darceleen Commodore.

H-10983-09
PAGE 13
Detective Morton met with Detective Desmond Pratt on the Mazant Street Scene.
Detective Pratt stated subjects on the scene identified the deceased at "Jessie Bibbins".
Several members of Bibbins' family were present at the scene.
A member of the Jessie Bibbins' family, Nicole Johnson, identified his remains on the
Mazant Street Scene. Based on the information given by one of the two eyewitnesses to
the Tricou Street shooting, and the proximity of two scenes Jessie Bibbins, black male, of
1815 Carondelet Street, was developed as a suspect.
Detective Morton met with Detective Gregory Hamilton on the Mazant Street scene.
Detective Hamilton interviewed Jasmine Blue of 1739 Mazant Street. Blue stated she was
in her back yard when she heard a male voice screaming "call 911". As she entered her
front yard she observed a subject clad in black unresponsive outside 1731 Mazant Street
being attended to by a second black male subject. Blue phoned police via 911. Blue also
stated she did not hear gunfire prior to discovering the wounded subject, and she had not
seen the either subject in the neighborhood prior to the incident.
Detective Hamilton also met with Lawrence Gordon on the scene. Gordon stated he
was riding his bicycle in the 1700 block of Mazant Street when he observed two male
subjects on the steps of 1731 Mazant Street. The subject assisting the injured subject
requested Gordon phone police. The subject also advised Gordon the injured man is the
son of the Head Football Coach at Carver High School and is possibly named "Jessie".
Gordon also stated he had not seen either subject in the neighborhood prior to the
incident.
Detective Morton met with the owner of 1731Mazant Street, Nicole Johnson, who is
also the cousin of deceased male subject. Johnson identified the subject as her cousin,
Jessie Bibbins.
While on the Mazant Street scene Detective Morton met with a concerned citizen,
who advised him Bibbins staggered from the corner of North Derbigny Street and sat
down on the front steps at 1713 Mazant Street alone. The citizen did not see or hear a
vehicle.
At around 1:00am, Detective Aucoin located a set of keys, which were hanging from a
key box in the living room of the residence. Detective Aucoin checked the keys and was
successful in locating a key to the front door of the residence. Detective Aucoin,
believing that he had exhausted the scene for night, locked and secured the residence and
placed a seal from the Orleans Parish Coroner's Office on the door. Detective Aucoin
then spoke to two black females who identified themselves as family members of Patrice
Comadore, Marie Commodore and Indel Commodore.

H-10983-09
PAGE 14
Neither female offered any information pertinent to the investigation and where
mainly concerned with the residence being secured.
At this point, Detective Aucoin released the scene and relocated to the secondary
scene in the 1700 block of Mazant Street. The scene on Mazant Street was handled by
Detective Pratt of the Homicide Section.
At around 12:00AM Detective Mathews complied photographic line-ups of both
suspects at the Homicide Office. The line-ups were compiled of booking photographs of
the suspects and individuals with similar physical characteristics. The images are chosen
by computer. The line-ups would be used for viewing by the witnesses.
Detectives Morton and Orlando Mathews proceeded to the Homicide Office to
interview the two witnesses. At 12:47AM Detective Morton interviewed Earlitta Taylor,
who stated she and the Commodore sisters are close friends. She and her four year old
son were inside the residence at the time of the shooting. Taylor was in the kitchen. She
heard a loud crash from the front of the home and men's voices demanding everyone get
on the floor. She heard two distinctly male voices demanding money. One of the
perpetrators, who was clad in dark clothing confronted Taylor with a firearm while in the
kitchen. Taylor pleaded with the subjects not to harm the children. One of the
perpetrators yelled "don't play with me bitch". The subject moved to an unknown section
of the residence out of Taylor's view. Taylor, while face down on the floor and pleaded
with the perpetrators not to harm the infant children. At that point there was a single
gunshot. Both subjects exited the residence. Taylor observed the victim, Patrice
Commodore, lying in a puddle of blood at the entrance to the bedroom. Taylor sat with
Patrice Commodore until police arrived.
At 12:31AM Patrice Commodore's remains were removed from the Tricou Street
scene by Orleans Parish Coroner's Office Investigator Parnell Williams.
At 12:55AM Jessie Bibbins' remains were removed from the Mazant Street crime
scene by Orleans Parish Coroner's Office Investigator Parnell Williams.
At 1:25AM Detectives Barret Morton entered the interview room occupied by
witness, Darceleen Commodore, with the aforementioned photographic line-up of
Kendall Gordon. Detective Morton requested the witness think back to the incident and
the subjects she observed fatally shoot the victim inside the vehicle earlier this date inside
her residence. The witness was instructed to take her time and view each photograph. The
witness was then furnished the photographic line-up of Kendall Gordon. The witness
carefully viewed the line-up. Commodore stated the person, who entered her home was
the man in photograph number three, Kendall Gordon, who she has known from the
neighborhood.

At 1:50AM Detectives Barret Morton interviewed Darceleen Commodore regarding
the identification of the second perpetrator. Detective Morton requested the witness
think back to the incident and the subjects she observed fatally shoot her sister inside
the vehicle earlier this date inside her residence. The witness was instructed to take her
time and view each photograph. The witness was then furnished the photographic line-
up of Jessie Bibbins. The witness carefully viewed the line-up. Commodore stated the
person, who entered her home was the man in photograph number two, Jessie Bibbins,
but she is only 90% sure as he looked older than the booking photograph.

At 1:56AM Detective Morton interviewed Darceleen Commodore at the Homicide
Office. Commodore stated she and her sister resided at 1810 Tricou with there infant
children. On the night of the shooting Darceleen stated she was in the living room of the
residence on the computer when she heard a loud crash at the front door. She observed
two subjects armed with handguns enter the residence both subjects were clad in dark
clothing. One had his face partially covered with a black bandana and the second
subject's face was partially covered with a red bandana. Both subject enetered the front
bedroom out of her line of sight. She heard the two subjects demanding money and
vehicle keys from Patrice Commodore. There was a brief struggle and a single gunshot.
The subject in the black bandana, later identified as Kendall Gordon, pulled the subject in
the red bandanna, later identified as Jessie Bibbins, into the hallway. Gordon argued with
and yelled at Bibbins regarding the gunshot. Gordon then forced the witness to the front
bedroom demanding money.

H-10983-09
PAGE 16
At that point the witness observed her sister unresponsive and bleeding on the floor at
the entrance to the bedroom. Gordon stated he would kill the witness if the police arrived
while he was inside the residence. Both perpetrators then exited the residence with n
money, or car keys. The witness notified then police.
At 2:30AM Crime Lab Technician Tamika Rogers, Unit 5137, conducted gunshot
residue test on both Darceleen Commodore and Earlitta Taylor at the Homicide Office.
The test were logged into Central Evidence and Property by Technician Rogers under
control number: 200912717.
Based on the positive identification of Kendall Gordon an arrest warrant was prepared
for Gordon by Detective Morton for the suspect for two counts of R.S.14:30, relative to
First Degree Murder. At 3:15AM Detective Morton met with Magistrate Judge Marie
Bookman. After reviewing the document the judge affixed her signature to the document
issuing an arrest warrant for Kendall Gordon.
On Sunday August 9, at 9:00AM, the post-mortem examinations of Patrice
Commodore and Jessie Bibbins were conducted at the Orleans Parish Forensic Center.
The examinations were conducted by Doctor Robert Tracy. Patrice Commodore suffered
a fatal gunshot wound to the head, a gunshot wound to the right wrist, and a gunshot
wound to the right arm. Jessie Bibbins suffered a single gunshot wound to the neck
puncturing the Aorta, causing massive interval bleeding. During the examinations one
spent pellet was recovered from Patrice Commodore and one spent pellet was recovered
from Jessie Bibbins. Both were logged into Central Evidence and Property under control
number 200912839 by Detective David Trehan.
At around 5:45PM, Kendall turned himself in to New Orleans Police at the Fifth
District Station. The suspect was placed under arrest and advised of his rights per
Miranda by Officer Carolyn Dalton. The suspect was transported to the Homicide
Office. Detective Morton met with the suspect at the Homicide Office and re-advised him
of his rights per-Miranda via New Orleans Police Rights of Arrestee Form number
250651. The suspect indicated he understood his rights and did not make any statements
to Detective Morton. Gordon was then transported to Central Lock up by Detective
Morton were he was booked accordingly.
On Monday August 10, at 1:00PM Detective Morton received a copy of the
communication log from the command desk. The Detective requested an audio taped
copy of all telephone and police radio transmissions regarding the accident.
At 2:00PM Detective Morton received a copy of the Fifth District Incident Report
from the Fifth District. Detective Morton reviewed the document and found it consistent
with his observations on the scene.

H-10983-09
PAGE 17
On Tuesday August 11, at around 3:00PM Detective Morton met with Jessie Bibbins'
mother, Reynell Payne, and father Jessie Bibbins Senior, at 3412 Montague Street.
Detective was advised by Jessie Bibbins senior that his son had been a discipline problem
and had moved in with relatives in Harvey, Louisiana. He also stated there are at least
two subjects at the Harvey residence, Curtis and Donald Palrean, who would be negative
influences on his son. Bibbins' mother, Reynell Payne advised Detective Morton her
sister, Nicole Johnson, had witnessed Curtis Pelrean and Jessie Bibbins practicing a home
invasion robbery at the Harvey home. Payne also stated she met with a subject known to
her as Kerry Batiste, who stated his niece was the victim of a murder on Tricou Street
over the weekend, and her sister was a witness to the shooting. According to Payne she
met with witness Darceleen Commodore and asked her to view a photograph containing
both Curtis Palrean and Jessie Bibbins junior. Payne states Commodore became
emotional and pointed at Curtis Palrean and stated he was one of the subjects in her
home. Payne then pointed at Jessie Bibbins and asked if he was one of the perpetrators,
Commodore replied "no"
At 4:30PM Detective Morton interviewed Jessie Bibbins junior's girlfriend, Erica Tate, at
Tate stated she and Bibbins had been dating for several months
and she was unaware he was involved in criminal activity of any sort. When asked about
Bibbins' friends she stated the one subject who would have information on the shooting
and Bibbins would be a subject known to her as "Jonas".According to Tate Jessie Bibbins
and "Jonas" are best friends and see each other daily often in the Ninth Word.
On Wednesday August 12, at around 10:00AM, Detective Morton met with Curtis
Palrean at his residence,
Harvey. Detective Morton requested the
subject submit to being interviewed at the New Orleans Police Homicide Office. At 11:00
Detective Morton met with Palrean at the Homicide Office. Detective Morton advised
Palrean of his rights via New Orleans Police Rights of Suspect Form number 250652.
Palrean indicated he understood his rights and that he was under investigation. Palrean
waived his rights and requested he be allowed to give a statement to police. Palrean stated
he is the uncle of Jessie Bibbins junior and that they have a close relationship. According
to Palrean, on the evening of the shooting he and Bibbins sat in the living room while
Bibbins anxiously waited for an unknown subject to pick him up. At around 6:30PM
Bibbins exited the residence. Palrean states he went to sleep in the living room and was
awaken hours later by another occupant of the home, Brenda Spencer, who advised him
Bibbins had been killed. Palrean also stated he has seen Bibbins in possession of fire
arms on several occasions.
At 5:00PM Detective Morton received a phone call from Reynell Payne demanding her
son not be named as a perpetrator as the burial and life insurance policies would not be
valid if her son died while committing a felony.

....
PAGE 18
H-10983-09
At 12:55PM, Detective Morton met with another occupant of
Nicole Johnson, who stated she has seen Bibbins in possession of firearms at the
residence. On the evening of the shooting she left the residence at around 8:00PM and
visited friends in New Orleans. She received a phone call from a neighbor advising her a
subject had been shot and was on the front lawn of her former residence, 1713 Mazant
Street. Johnson relocated to the scene were she identified the deceased subject as Jessie
Bibbins.
At 2:00PM, Detective Morton interviewed the owner and occupant of 1810
Chriswood Street, Brenda Spencer, who stated on the evening of the shooting she was at
home with Curtis Palrean, and she had awaken Palrean and notified him of the shooting.
At 1:00PM Detective Morton submitted Crime Lab Request Form requesting blood
samples collected from the scene at 1810 Tricou Street be prepped for DNA testing
against evidence collected from Jessie Bibbins during the post-mortem examination.
Detective Morton also requested the ballistics evidence collected at the scene, two spent
9mm casings, be compared to the two pellets collected at the autopsies.
On Thursday August 13, at 2:00PM, Detective Barret Morton received a copy of the
Coroner's Office Day Records from Detective David Trehan. The documents officially
classified the shooting deaths of Patrice Commodore and Jessie Bibbins as a Homicides.
At 9:00AM Detective Morton met with witness, Darceleen Commodore at her
residence regarding her encounter with Reynell Payne. Commodore advised the
Detective that Reynell Payne pressured her to say her son wasn't one of the perpetrators
and the older gentleman was the perpetrator. Commodore states the statement given to
Detective Morton on the night of the incident is an accurate account of her observations.
On Tuesday August 18, at around 3PM, Detective Barret Morton met with the best
friend of Jessie Bibbins, Jonas Taylor at his residence. Taylor had spoken to Reynell
Payne several times prior to meeting with police. Taylor stated he and Bibbins talked
daily and spent time in the Ninth Ward. Taylor advised the Detective he was unaware
Bibbins and Gordon were associates and had never seen them together. On the evening of
the shooting Taylor stated he received a phone call from Bibbins at around 9:00PM.
Bibbins stated he was in a vehicle with his uncles.
On August 24, Detective Morton received a copy of the Crime Scene Report from the
Crime Lab. The eighteen page document contained a list of photographs taken, a compact
disc containing the scene photographs, a detailed scene sketch, and receipts for evidence
collected at both crime scenes.

With the arrest of Kendall Gordon the case is considered cleared.
